title: po nightshift worker woken up
story: Exclusive: PO nightsht worker woken up by security guard to be told hes lost his jobProtestors descended on Parliament this afternoon to condemn POs sacking of  workers last week. Crowds chanted no to PO and shame on you as Labour MPs made speeches Image: REUTERSByAletha AduPolitical Correspondent:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsA former PO Ferriesapos nightsht worker has recalled the moment he realised he had lost his job - a security guard woke him up and urged him to “pack up and get off” the ship. The engineer, from Dover, said he slept through the infamous Zoom call as he had been on a long sht overnight. Having worked at the company for three years, he told the Mirror there were no signs that the mass sacking was set to take place. “It was crazy, there was so much confusion with all the security guards coming”, the engineer told the Mirror. “They had handcuffs and were positioned all around the ship to prevent us from taking things, or clearly just in case people got angry and refused to leave.”  The engineer claimed the company had promised to help staff move their belongings from the ship as they live on sea for half of the year. “But they didn’t, they just left us”, he claimed. He was one of dozens sacked PO Ferries staff who marched on Parliament this afternoon to express their anger and disgust at how they were treated. Last Thursday PO made a shock announcement, telling staff via video message that they were being replaced immediately by cheaper agency crew. A senior officer, also at the protest, claims he got a text at .am on Thursday morning that there was “bad news”, and he was urged to watch the Zoom call at .. “It came completely out of the blue”, he told the Mirror.“They were ordering unorm for us earlier in the week. The night before we completed a normal handover, and seniors even told me ‘see you next week’. “I’m not sure what I will do. I’ve worked with PO for  years. It was the first job I got once I finished school.” Labour MPs including Angela Rayner, Barry Gardiner, Jonathan Reynolds, Karl Turner, Zarah Sultana showed solidarity with the protestors outside the Commons. Ms Rayner told the crowd: “My message to PO is quite simple you said you needed to save money, well look what it’s done to your company now, look what people think of your company now!  “And any other company that thinks they can do something like this, I say to them, we’ll come for your next. This has to stop now.” Hull East MP Karl Turner condemned PO as a “disgusting, stinking, capitalist, predatory company”, and said he had spoken with devastated former workers including a man who was  months from retirement when he was sacked.Mr Turner said: “ had the chance in the past and they’ve let the side down. It’s no goodGrant Shapps coming out now with his crocodile tears. He could do something to act today.“A man I spoke to started as a deckhand at  years of age, he’s a first mate now. He’s got  months before he retires.crying like a baby to me about the disgust and the fact that he felt so betrayed by this disgusting, stinking, capitalist, predatory company.” In a message to the Government, Frances O’Grady, general secretary of the TUC said: “PO want to rob their livelihoods. If you let them get away with this, then every worker will believe that they are coming after us next. “Loyal hardworking workers were being escorted off ferries by guards. We are not going to let them get away with it.”  Ms O’Grady urged the gathering not to taken their anger out on the replacement crew who are being paid £., according to unions, saying: “Migrant workers are not the enemies. Bad bosses are.” Mum-of-three Heather, , expressed her disappointment at PO’s behaviour because she has struggled to get a job as a master marina because of childcare and maternity leave. Mum-of-three Heather said PO had been one of the few companies to offer family-friendly hours.  “It’s hard working at sea as a woman”, she told the Mirror, “Iaposm gutted for all of my former colleagues who have lost their jobs and I’m here at this protest in full support of them. “I’m also gutted because PO were one of the only companies,not the only company, that I knew that did job shares and enabled a mother like myself to work on a family friendly sht pattern.” Heather used to work part time at PO until she had her last child. story: things Rishi Sunak could do to put more money in your pocket - and why he wont botherHelping the poor requires knowing what its like to be one of them, says Fleet Street FoxMore money for poorer people  Whats the point of that  Image: via REUTERSopinionByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsThis week a man who has delivered more tax rises than any Chancellor of the past half a century will get up on his hind legs and tell you he wants to cut them. Raise the NI thresholdNext month everyone with a job, and every firm, will be paying more for the privilege. Make Brexit betterThe UK waved goodbye to £bn of cross-border trade with Boris Johnsonaposs bad Brexit deal this year, at just the time the effects were worse thanks to the pandemic and, now, the war crime spree in Ukraine. Thereaposs a simple way to restore every penny of it, though, which is to end all tarfs and customs checks by complying with EU standards on goods and services.It turns out, they werenapost so bad after all. story: State pension could rise % in  in Tory pledge - but only after year of cutsThe DWP re-stated its commitment to the triple lock next year in a hasty clarication, despite soaring inflation. It would mean pensioners get a bumper rise next year after cuts this year in a benefits rollercoasterTherese Coffey insisted the triple lock will be brought back in   Image: Barcroft Media via Getty ImagesByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Mar |commentsPensions could rise by more than % next April after the DWP insisted it “remains committed” to bringing back the triple lock - despite soaring inflation.Officials said welfare chief Therese Coffey plans to keep a pledge to base April ’s state pension rise on average wages, .%, or this September’s CPI inflation figure - whichever is highest. That will likely see a bumper rise for pensioners next Spring - but only after a year of hefty real-terms cuts. The Resolution Foundation has predicted inflation could hit .% this September, higher than last year though still below a peak next month of .%. That would lead to a pensions rise of more than £ a week in April . But the think tank blasted the “rollercoaster ride” for the benefits system and urged ministers to ease pressure now. The announcement came in a hasty clarication from the DWP, hours after the Work and Pensions Secretary publicly failed to guarantee the triple lock’s future. The DWPaposs clarication was not a full-blown guarantee and left room for a U-turn later on. But sources insisted Ms Coffey was fully planning on bringing back the triple lock in  .  Ms Coffey suspended the triple lock - a solemn manesto pledge - for one year in   because post-Covid wages were bouncing back in an “anomaly”.That sparked fury as it meant the state pension will rise by only .% next month, less than inflation. That is a real-terms cut of £ to Britain’s million pensioners, Shadow DWP chief Jon Ashworth said. With inflation soaring, Mr Asworth today demanded she rule out breaking the triple lock again in   during a House of Commons debate. The DWP chief did not do so, leading Mr Ashworth to blast: “Thérèse Coffey has just refused to guarantee she won’t break the triple lock for a second year in a row. “Pensioner poverty is up, bills are up, and pensioners are facing a real terms cut to the state pension of over £ this year. The Conservatives are failing to give them the security they deserve in retirement. “The simple truth is pensioners simply can’t trust the Tories.” Hours later, the DWP issued a clarication saying Ms Coffey “remains committed” to the triple lock in  .  A DWP spokesperson said: “We temporarily suspended the earnings element - not CPI - of the Triple Lock for one year only, following distortions to the earnings statistics. “The government remains committed to implementing the Triple Lock in the usual way for the remainder of the Parliament. No said it “can’t predict” inflation in future but insisted there was “no change” to the commitment.Askedthe previous promise to bring back the triple lock for   still stood, Boris Johnson ’s official spokesman added: “It does.“We’ve made clear it was a temporary pause. “I can’t and no one can predict what inflationary pressure will be, but certainly there’s no change to the commitment we have made.” Labour warned MoneySavingExpert founder Martin Lewis was right to say people will either starve or freeze from the cost of living crisis. story: Surgeries shutting as burnt-out doctors see  patients a day in Uber-isation of GPsThe British Medical Association warned doctors are so overburdened that every GP practice would have to close its list to new patients due to safety fearsThe previous safe limit was  patients Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByMartin BagotHealth and Science editor:,  Mar |commentsA hundred GP practices are closing every year because they do not have enough doctors to treat their catchment area. The British Medical Association also said “realistically every GP practice should close its patient list” due to unsafe patient numbers.The comments came at the launch of a joint campaign with ex-Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt calling on Boris Johnson to tackle the crisis in general practice.Mr Hunt, a former sworn enemy of the BMA, said we are seeing the “Uber-isation of general practice” with patients forced to see a dferent doctor every time. Lack of GPs means that on average each is seeing  patients a day. The previous safe maximum was . Dr Kieran Sharrock, BMA committee deputy chair GP Committee England, BMA, said: “Your practice may soon no longer exist. On current trajectory your local surgery may have to close.  “In the last eight years over  practices have closed. Two and half million patients have lost access to their family doctor.“If the Government doesn’t act now every family who relies on the NHS will find basic healthcare under threat.”Mr Hunt, the BMA and the GPDF, which represents local medical committees, yesterday launched the “rebuild general practice” campaign. Mr Hunt said the GP workforce shortage had meant an end to “continuity of care” - where a patient sees the same GP. At a media briefing in Marylebone, central London, he said: “The best thing about the NHS is having your own family doctor. “We know from studies that there’s a % less chance of a patient going to hospital and a % less chance of a patient dyingthey have the same GP over a long period of time.  “And that is because it is fundamentally safer to make a diagnosisyou know a patient’s context, you know their family, their social situation. You’re more likely to see those red flags when you should. “What I’m afraid we’re moving towards is the Uberisation of general practice where you see a dferent GP every time.” He joked he was “surprised” to be sitting on the same  as BMA members after being embroiled in a bitter row with the union over new contracts for junior doctors in . Mr Hunt acknowledged he failed to increase GP numbers by , as promised by the Tories during his stint as health secretary from  to . He said: “I didn’t fail to recruit enough GPs. I failed to recruit enough to make up for those that were leaving the profession”. Dr Sharrock said the main issue was stopping GPs leaving the profession, adding: “I speak to colleagues day in day out who have gone part time. “They say its because the job isn’t do-able. It isn’t safe. They don’t want to sully their career by not safely caring their patients. So they’re getting out.  “There are processes where practices going through a short term problem can close their lists for a period of time. “But realistically every practice should close its list because we can’t take the workload we are already doing. “If the pressure on GPs continues so they think it is unsafe, it can take one or two of them to leave and suddenly you can’t run the practice. “We have a contract with the NHS and at any point we can gave three months notice and say ‘actually we can’t run this contract any more.” The Rebuild General Practice campaign has released polling from , British GPs which found that nearly nine in  fear patients are not always safe at their surgeries.Asked about the survey on Times Radio, current Health Secretary Sajid Javid said: “We’re investing more in NHS workforce than ever before in history, and just in the last year there’s some , more people working for the NHS - that includes around , more doctors.“And we have more doctors in training at medical school than any other time in history.” In  the Tories promised , new GPs by . However once trainees are excluded, the GP workforce has shrunk by  during that period to , - below the level it was back in . story: Mum with headache told shes got ticking-time bomb tumour during routine eye checkKarly Cox, from Midsomer Norton, was diagnosed with a ocular melanoma, an eye cancer that develops from pigment-producing cells, and credits her routine trip to Specsavers with saving her leKarly Cox Image: Kennedy News and MediaByNia PriceZoe ForseyFeatures Editor:,  Mar |comments When Karly Cox popped to Specsavers for her regular check up, she expected the optician to give her a stronger prescription to tackle her recent headaches.But the routine check uncovered something much more sinister - a ticking-time bomb tumour - and saved her le. After the experts at her local branch in Midsomer Norton noticed a strange shadow in her scan in January, she was sent to Bristol Eye Hospital where she was told she had ocular melanoma - an eye cancer that develops from pigment-producing cells.The -year-old started radiotherapy last month at Moorfields Eye Hospital NHS Foundation Trust and willin August for scans which will revealsheaposs in the all-clear.But the full-time-mum has since lost her vision in her left eye and claims that simple everyday tasks, like doing her make-up, have been made far trickier since having the treatment. Now two weeks post-procedure, Karly is hopeful that her vision will eventually improve and is keen to raise awareness of the importance of having routine eye tests given her tumour was spotted in the aposnick of timeapos. Specsavers optometrist Kaye Bradley said that itaposs aposvitalapos to see an optometristyou have any changes in your vision and that the Optical Coherence Tomography scan can help diagnose many eye conditions, as well as help make urgent hospitals when necessary.Karly, of Radstock, Somerset, said: Having that eye test pretty much saved my le. You have an eye test every couple of years andIaposd left it andit was ocular melanoma because theyaposve treated it as that because it was too small to biopsy and it was presenting as that, it would have spread to my liver. I just want people to be aware to get their eyes tested because itaposs really important. Make sure that when you go and get your eyes tested, that you have that extra test becauseI didnapost have it, then I wouldnapost have even known and it would have been a lot worse because I would have lost my eye. I definitely caught it just in the nick of time and they told me I was lucky because usually people my age donapost get it, itaposs usually  and over. Karly, who has been wearing glasses since the age of three, has routine eye tests and had the Optical Coherence Tomography scan during her appointment last month.  She said: They offered me the extra health eye check and I went with it. She brought up the pictures on the screen and at first we thought it was just a shadow. It wasnapost until we looked at it closely and she was like aposoh, itaposs not a shadowapos she wasnapost too sure what it was and she was really concerned so she said the best thing for me to do was to go to Bristol Eye Hospital. I went and had loads of dferent eye tests and they sent me up for a CT scan and said that they thought I had ocular melanoma. But at this point, I didnapost know what it was. Then he started talking about radiotherapy and when he said aposradiotherapyapos I thought aposoh, thataposs cancerapos. The mum was then referred to Moorfields Eye Hospital NHS Foundation Trust where she stayed for three days to have her radioactive plaque treatment.  During the procedure a small metal disc was placed onto the surface of her eyeball over her tumour which gives out radioactive energy, with most of it directed inwards towards the tumour. Karly said: At first, it [receiving diagnosis] didnapost really click. The impact of it hasnapost really hit me until now I canapost see, now itaposs more upsetting for me because I canapost see anything. My vision is so blurry now, I canapost see out of my eye at all. If I look to the left itaposs just black. They did say that my eyesight would slowly come back and would slowly deteriorate. It all depends on how my body reacts to the radiotherapy. Every day is dferent for me. Every day I wake up and I see something dferent - it might be blurry, it might be fuzzy or I might have double vision. I never know what Iaposm going to wake up to. Iaposm hoping that Iaposll wake up one morning and my visionaposs a bit better, enough so I can see. Karly, whoaposs aposstill coming to termsapos with her impaired vision, said her eye is currently red and sore and that she wonapost know until a couple of months how much vision sheaposs lost. Karly said: I just want to go back and do normal things again. I havenapost been out shopping on my own. Iaposm too worried and get really anxious because I canapost see on my left sidesomeone walks by the side of me. Even just little things, like doing my make-up, are really hard because I canapost see. I canapost draw my eyebrows on because I canapost see and get a lot of double vision so canapost really see and do things how I did before. I have been hiding my face and put my hair right over it so you canapost see that side just because itaposs easier. Looking back now, Iaposve always suffered from really bad headaches and theyaposre one of the symptoms. I noticed at Christmas that I kept getting rings around lights and kept seeing floaty things. story: Cat too fat for door flap sheds the pounds - and is now looking for a new homeMotsys size meant she was unable to get in and out of the cat flap in her pod at the animal centre. Weighing more than kg, she has now lost .kg and is looking for a new homeShe has now lost .kg and is looking for a new homeBySamantha Mordi:,  Mar |commentsA -year-old cat who weighed the same as a small dog has shed the pounds - and is now looking for a new home. Motsy came into the RSPCAaposs Newport Animal Centre last October after her owner sadly passed away. She weighed .kg - more than twice the weight of an average adult cat and roughly the same as a small dog. Motsyaposs size meant she was unable to get in and out of the cat flap in her pod at the animal centre. Staff at the Newport Animal Centre in Wales, decided that being in a foster home would help her to lose weight and get more exercise. Fosterer Danni Wilson has been looking after Motsy at her home in Newport since November - and the cat now needs a full time home. Danni said: At first she was very nervous and had a particular fear of hands, so I started off by initially stroking her with my head. In the following weeks and months her personality really started to shine through and now she follows me around and likes to play and have a fuss, although everything is very much on her own terms.  We think she became overweight as a result of helping herself to her previous owneraposs food and never going outside to get exercise, although sheaposs slowly started to show an interest in my garden and likes to sit by the back door and enjoy the sun. The weight has gradually begun to come off - sheaposs already lost an two kilogramsand she can now just about reach the base of her tail. She said: But sheaposs still very heavy and will need to continue to shed some pounds to get down to a healthier size. Kath Logan, deputy manager at the centre, said: We think Motsy is the heaviest cat weaposve ever rehomed. Sheaposs a beautul girl who has come such a long way and we are all so proud of her. Sheaposs now feeling much more comfortable in her own skin, but she still struggles to groom herself properly, so she will appreciate an owner that is able to give her a helping hand with this for the foreseeable future. Itaposs also very important that she continues with a sensible feeding regime to enable her to carry on losing weight, and this is something we will discuss with potential owners. Staff feel Motsy would be best suited to an adult home with no other pets with a secure garden or a catio for her to spend time outside. title: child q right sue school
story: Child Q is right to sue school and police but we must crush racist culture for our kidsWeve reached a watershed moment, says Darren Lewis, and we must all call out racism to fix the crisis in educationRally at Hackney town hall for Child Q Image: Humphrey NemaropinionByDarren Lewis:,  Mar This weekend’s outpouring of ­emotion has been just the tip of the ­iceberg. On Thursday night, the protests began over Child Q – the black teenager scandalously strip-searched by police while menstruating at her school in Hackney, East London.The anger continued on Saturday and Sunday as thousands of adults and kids of all races and faiths voiced their contempt. More protests are planned in and outside the borough.Absolutely right too. Child Q’s private parts were exposed during the search. She was asked to bend over and cough by police who dragged her out of an exam because a teacher wrongly suspected her of carrying drugs. At her school hundreds of pupils went on strike last week, refusing to attend lessons and staging sit-ins. Teenagers at other schools in Hackney are preparing similar acts of defiance this week. They don’t feel safe. They don’t feel protected. How can they when – as the report into the scandal confirms – teachers leave the room and give officers carte blanche instead of acting in loco parentis  Who acts as the chaperone or the witness for Child Q’s defence  Who is there to tell the officers they are crossing the line And where, still, is the condemnation from Home Secretary Priti Patel or her boss, Boris Johnson I’d have gone ballisticChild Q had been my daughter. What breaks my heart as a dad is that so many of us parents have long since made our girlsaware of their rights so that no teacher or police officer could ever try to violate them in that way. Because the truth is that this kind of outrage tends to happen moreyou are black. The official report concludes as much on top of what we know already. But this weekend’s fightback is a line in the sand. A move towards real solutions – in Hackney and beyond. More black parents and s are signing up to become school governors. Kids are educating themselves on the legal boundaries for teachers and police. Because with a teacher we I am obviously supportive of the profession but some are entitled. Patronising towards parents and simply unwilling to listen to black children. Teenagers are using their voices to ensure they are not left as abandoned and traumatised as Child Q was in the room of that Hackney school. We’ve reached a watershed moment. Now the police have to be removed from our places of education. Especially the schools comprising pupils from poorer backgrounds and ethnic minorities. Once called upon, the report says, four officers arrived. You can see why Child Q would have been intimidated into complying with their demands. Much as the police and teachers might like to claim otherwise, the numbers suggest black children are racially discriminated against from an early age. A report from the Georgetown Law Centre on Poverty and Inequality, in Washington, D.C, US, found that adults saw black girls “as less inno­cent and more adult-like than white girls of the same age, espe­cial­ly between five- years old”. As such, they are presumed guilty when accused and treated more harshly by authority figures. And, surprise, surprise, black Caribbean students in our schools are excluded up to six times more than their white counterparts. Child Q has further exposed a crisis in our education system. Like you or I would, she is rightly suing the living daylights out of the school and police. story: Couple told to pay £, for dogs le-saving op TWO DAYS after buying herRaf and Daria Cieslicka, from Southport, were told that their -week-old cockapoo Bella must go under the kne within a weekshe has any chance of survivalBella the cockapoo needs urgent le-saving treatment Image: Raf Cieslicki Liverpool EchoByBenjamin Roberts-HaslamLaura SharmanNews Reporter:,  Mar |commentsA couple were told that their new puppy needs a le-saving £, operation - just two days after buying her.Raf and Daria Cieslicka were given the devastating news within  hours of buying -week-old cockapoo puppy Bella. The pair, from Southport, Merseyside, now have to raise £, in a week to save her le after she was diagnosed with patent ductus arteriosus .The defect can be deadlyleft untreated and consists of a hole in an artery that fails to close after birth. Vets requested that Bella go under the kne within a week for her to have any chance of survival, due to her condition being previously undiagnosed. Her operation is scheduled for March . Raf and Daria, originally from Poland, saw Bella advertised online and were reassured that the puppy had undergone standard health checks.  Two days after collecting the pup, they took her to the vets for a check-up and were told the heartbreaking news that she would need urgent surgery. Daria, , said: Three weeks ago, on February , we bought the dog off this private seller. We were told sheaposs had health checks and that she was brilliant so we believed them and bought her. After two days we took her to the vet who checked her. She said she needed a scan. So we booked the scan for the following week and the scan found that she had PDA which means she has a hole in an artery. She now needs an operation to close the hole. After this, we hope sheaposll be fine but we canapost get anyone to insure her because she has a pre-existing health condition. When we rang the seller and they denied selling her to us. After we said they did, the person just said it was their dad and that he would ring us. Since then we havenapost heard from them and they wonapost answer the phone. We were hoping they would pay for the operation becausewe gave her back they would probably kill her since she wouldnapost earn them any money. If the family do not manage to raise the money, they plan on taking out a loan to fund the operation. title: disappointed runner set up barkrun
story: Disappointed runner to set up Barkrun as parkrun brings in new safety rulesKevin Ward participates in parkruns at Suffolks Kesgrave with his dog but is hoping to create an alternative Barkrun event in response to their new rules for dog ownersRunners, walkers and dogs enjoy parkrun at Levengrove Image: Lennox HeraldByPaige FreshwaterContent Editor:,  Mar |commentsAs parkrun prepares to change its rules for runners who participate with dogs, one owner is planning to set up an alternative event in protest. From Saturday, April , parkrun will no longer allow runner to use a waist harneses when participating in the five-kilometre run with their dogs.They state clear evidence shows an increased risk to peopleaposs safety when running alongside another participant with a dog, with some becoming tangled in or tripping over the dogaposs lead.But Kevin Ward, , who runs at Kesgrave, in Suffolk, with his dog, Wilson, says his pet has become so wellknown people have begun cheering him on during their runs.  Disappointed by the new rules, Kevin is hoping to set up a similar event in Kesgrave, called Barkrun, where owners will be able to exercise their pets while using either a harness, short or long lead. Under parkrunaposs new rules, dogs should be kept on a short, handheld, non-extendable lead by the side of the participant and should remain within reach at all time. Only one dog is allowed per participant and care must be taken to avoid tripping other parkrunners. A statement from parkrun reads: Over ten percent of incidents at parkrun events involve dogs, and as such we have spent signicant time considering the nature, frequency, and severity of dog-related incidents. Our evidence shows that, when participants use waist harnesses, there is an increased risk of serious incidents, particularly trips and falls, compared to when using handheld leads. These are typically associated with dogs running in front of other participants, and are occurring when people are together in groups, when people with dogs are overtaking others, and when people with dogs are being overtaken.  Unfortunately, the nature of parkrunning with a waist harness is such that the lead allows dogs to move from side to side, in front of the participant, which can result in the dog suddenly and unexpectedly crossing in front of other participants on the course.Despite assuring runners dogs are still welcome at parkrun, members have taken to Facebook to vent their frustration at new rules.One user said: This is such a shame. It was great to get out and exercise my dog while I run. I feel it is much more unsafe to be running with a dog in a handheld lead, you can end up letting go of the lead oryou fall you have no hands to catch yourself. I also love the way having my dog open up conversations and connections with other runners and I wonapost be running with my dog on a handheld lead. While another user added: This country is not dog friendly! They aren’t welcome in lots of places. I thought parkrun was dferent but it following suit. Lots of dog haters on here that have no clue! The parkrun statement adds: Since the earliest days of parkrun, we’ve openly welcomed people participating with their dogs. Paul Sinton-Hewitt, the founder of parkrun, would participate in the Bushy Park Time Trial with his, and we’ve always felt that it was not only something that emphasised the informal nature of our events, but provided an opportunity for dog owners to participate where they otherwise might be excluded. Over the last  years however, we have grown from a single event into a global movement, with hundreds of thousands of weekly participants, across  dferent countries. As such we continually review our processes in order to balance accessibility and inclusivity with the safety of our participants and other park users. Importantly, we remain of the belief that, overall, the benefits of allowing participation with dogs far outweigh the risks of doing so. title: free range eggs no longer
story: Why are free range eggs no longer available in UK supermarkets - and what are barn eggs Free-range eggs are no longer available in UK supermarkets, and will not be for the foreseeable future. Heres everything you need to know about why free-range eggs are being labelled as barn eggs insteadFree-range eggs will be labelled barn eggs across UK supermarkets Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByMalvika PadinTrends Writer:,  Mar |comments Cases of avian flu, which began rising in the country in November, , have led to the biggest ever outbreak of bird flu in Great Britain and the death of thousands of birds. In order to keep cases under control amid the outbreak has resulted in the government enforcing an Avian Influenza Prevention Zone across the UK.While it should help to prevent case numbers from increasing, the prevention measures will mean that free-range eggs will not be able to be labelled as such in the near future. They were given a -week grace period, whereby farmers were able to maintain their free-range status, but this ended on March, , .Hereaposs why free-range eggs are being replaced in UK supermarkets.Why are free-range eggs no longer available in the UK   Free-range eggs, which accounts for % of all eggs produced in the UK according to RSPCA, come from birds that enjoy unlimited access to outdoor pastures during the daytime. Free-range laying hens can be kept indoors only for up to  weeks for their eggs to still be labelled free-range, however, this period has ended, with birds still being kept in containment, due to there still being a high level of risk to birds of catching flu.  A spokesperson for the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairsexplained: The -week grace period we allowed for free-range eggs has now been exceeded, and eggs must now be marketed as ‘barn eggs’. We have worked closely with the sector and retailers to implement these changes as smoothly as possible. The avian, or bird, flu outbreak controls mean that there is a legal requirement for all poultry farmers in the UK to keep their birds, whether pets or commercial flocks, indoors and follow strict biosecurity measures as well. What are barn eggs  Eggs in UK shops will no longer classy as free-range because the birds have been kept inside for more than  weeks. The eggs will therefore be labelled as barn eggs. This is the name given to eggs produced by permanently indoor birds. The British Retail Consortium said that signs will be put in supermarkets to inform shoppers of the change in labelling, adding that the previous free-range label willonly after the hens are permitted to go outside again. Andrea Martinez-Inchausti, assistant director of food at the British Retail Consortium, said shops and supermarkets would continue to support British farmers. What is avian flu and is it dangerous  According to the NHS, bird flu or avian flu is a highly infectious type of influenza that spreads among birds. The disease typically poses a very low risk to humans, though people have previously been infected by it around the world.With the UK facing its largest-ever outbreak of avian flu, the government has stated that it would work with farmers and retailers to implement any branding changes to eggs as long as the housing measures to protect poultry remain in place. story: How long can I test positive for Covid – and how many days symptoms can last With Covid cases surging in the UK, we take a look at how long symptoms last for, how long you might test positive for and how long you should self isolate forCovid infections are rising in the UK Image: Getty ImagesByAriane Sohrabi-ShirazSEO Editor:,  Mar |comments Covid infections in the UK have been steadily increasing since the end of February due to people mixing more after restrictions were axed in England. On March  alone there were , cases reported, however, health secretary Sajid Javid has said there is no particular cause for concern, as we now strive to live with the virus. The legal requirement to self isolateyou catch Covid has been dropped in England, and the government is ending the provision of free tests from April . People are now being urged to act with personal responsibility, although the NHS is still advising that you should stay at home and avoid contact with other people. If you do test positive for coronavirus, hereaposs some things you might want to know, including how long youaposll test positive and how long to self isolate for.How long will I test positive for Covid   Most people will stop testing positive for Covid within  days of starting to experience symptoms, or receiving their first positive test. However, itaposs possible to still test positive for weeks, or sometimes months after having the virus. Gavi, The Vaccine Alliance says itaposs possible to test positive for Covid- for weeks, but people are not likely to be contagious for very long.It explains: The time taken to test negative after contracting Covid- depends on the severity of the case, and also on the test itself. PCR tests that hunt out parts of viral genetic materialin our bodies and amply it so we can detect it are extremely sensitive and can even pick up the presence of few viral fragments. This is because fragments of viral RNA can remain in our bodies long after the infection is over and the virus has been cleared from our system.” In general, itaposs reported that asymptomatic people can test positive for one to two weeks, while those with mild-to-moderate disease continue to test positive for a week or more. How long should you self isolate for  You are no longer required by law to self isolate in England and Northern Ireland. However, the NHS recommends you stay at home and avoid contact with other people. You also no longer need to take daily Covid testsyouaposve been in close contact with someone with coronavirus in England. According to the NHS, you should stay at home while youaposre infectious to others. It adds: This can be up to  days from when your symptoms start. Many people will no longer be infectious to others after five days. The NHS recommends you do rapid lateral flow tests from five days after your symptoms startedand another the next day. It adds: If both tests are negative and you do not have a high temperature, youaposre less likely to pass Covid- to others and you can go back to your normal routine. If your test result is positive on day five, you can carry on doing rapid lateral flow tests every day until you get two negative test results in a row. In Scotland and Wales you are still required by law to self-isolate after testing positive for Covid. How long do symptoms last   According to the NHS, most people feel better within a few days or weeks and most people make a full recovery within  weeks.However, Covid symptoms can last longer.According to the Zoe Covid Study App, most people recover within two weeks, and one in  people have symptoms after three weeks. Those who suffer for longer than usual may have something called long Covid, which describes symptoms you may have after infection. title: madeleine mccann case closing after
story: Why is Madeleine McCann case closing after  years with no trace of youngsterAfter  years, a £ million fund, one prime suspect and zero convictions, the special investigation into the  disappearance of Madeleine McCann is due to be brought to a closeOperation Grange, title of the official politan Police probe into the Madeleine McCann case, is due to end Image: METROPOLITAN POLICE AFP via GettByHarry ThompsonTrends WriterMilo BoydNews Reporter:,  Mar  After  years, the special police investigation into the disappearance of British child Madeleine McCann while on holiday in Portugal is due to be brought to an end.Known as Operation Grange, the politan Police probe was launched four years after she went missing in  and was designed to cooperate with fellow investigating forces in Europe.Speaking to the Sun a source said: “There are currently no plans to take the inquiry any further.“The end of the road for Operation Grange is now in sight. The team’s work is expected to be completed by autumn.” The decision to can the probe has raised questions about whether or not the case’s prime suspect will be charged with the disappearance of the girl. Who is the prime suspect in the Madeleine McCann investigation German police have named their prime suspect as -year-old Christian Brueckner, who is currently in prison for separate crimes. German prosecutors say they have “concrete” evidence against him and is their only suspect, who is current serving a jail sentence for the rape of an American woman in . Brueckner was named as the prime suspect after phone records placed him at the Portuguese resort on the night Madeleine went missing. He has accused prosecutors of making “scandalous” claims against him, saying they bring “shame” on the German legal system. Why is the Madeleine McCann case going to end  The budget for the investigation is due to run out at the end of March, despite former Met Police chief Cressida Dick saying that the operation would only end once every lead had been probed. In the past few years, the size of the team working on Operation Grange has shrunk from  officers down to just four. Led by Detective Chief Inspector Mark Cranwell, the investigation is believed to have cost around £ million. The investigation has been spearheaded by German and Portuguese authorities, with Met cops in a supporting role. A request for more money has reportedly been sent into the Home Office, which would take the operation to the end of September. Could the Madeleine McCann case be reopened   Yes,there was a further breakthrough the case would be reopened - although detectives will not be actively investigating in the meantime. story: Postie, , sacked for sticking chewing gum on garden gate wins £, compensationGraham Harvey had a clean work record having been a postman for more than  years, but was sacked for his first misdemeanour. But an employment tribunal ruled he was unfairly dismissed as none of these actions should have amounted to a sackable offence. He has now been awarded £,. in compensation. The Scottish tribunal heard Mr Harvey had worked for Royal Mail for  years when he was sacked following the incident in .  He was based at its Prestonpans office near Edinburgh, where he had a predominantly rural route to deliver to. The hearing was told that in October that year, a customer visited the office to make a complaint about Mr Harvey. The complaint was that he had aposremoved a piece of chewing gum from his mouth and placed it on a gate lantern at the propertyapos. The incident was captured on CCTV footage which was emailed to his manager along with a photograph. The customeraposs email described the conduct as aposdisgustingapos, but he said he and his we did not wish to aposmake a huge fuss about itapos. The tribunal heard the video also showed Mr Harvey driving his vehicle without a seatbelt and leaving items of mail on the front passenger seat. On histo work the following Monday, Jordan Cree, the delivery office manager, asked Mr Harvey to have a word in his office. Mr Harvey admitted to driving without a seatbelt and leaving items of mail on his passenger seat but denied placing chewing gum on the customeraposs premises.  The tribunal heard he was suspended at the end of the meeting pending aposfurther investigations into an alleged incident where you have defaced a customeraposs propertyapos. A disciplinary meeting was held in October, when Mr Harvey admitted all of the allegations against him including the placing of chewing gum on the customeraposs property. He described it as a aposstupid decisionapos and said he had done it aposon two occasions at mostapos. He offered to apologise to the customer. He also admitted driving without a seatbelt in rural locations and added it was aposcommon practiceapos for him and for many others over many years,not decades, to drive without seatbelts in certain situations at certain locations. Concerns were also raised of potential aposmassive reputational damageapos to Royal Mail arising from the CCTV being placed on social media, but the tribunal heard no evidence any video being posted. He then lost an appeal with another manager saying he believed the chewing gum issue was a aposdeliberate act on [Mr Harveyaposs] part to cause anxiety and distressapos. Employment Judge Ronald Mackay ruled the dismissal was unfair, as not wearing a seatbelt and leaving mail on the passenger seat were aposcommon practicesapos known to management, while the chewing gum issue was not serious enough to be deemed gross misconduct. story: Pregnant women with Covid three times more likely to suffer dangerous blood clotIn the UK, mums-to-be who have not had the Covid jab make up a fth of the most ill patients in intensive care and were three times as likely to develop a blood clotThe Covid vaccine is safe for pregnant women and their babies Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByLiam Buckler:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsPregnant women who catch Covid are twice as likely to develop serious complications and three times more likely to suffer a potentially fatal blood, according to scientists.With coronavirus also doubling the risk of of premature birth, acute respiratory distress syndrome and sepsis, according to new research.Meanwhile, in the UK, mums-to-be who have not had the jab make up a fth of the most ill patients in intensive care, data showed. Infected patients who took part in this latest study were three times as likely to have a blood clot - known medically as a thromboembolism, scientists discovered. Thromboembolism can cause a blockage in the main artery of the lung or form where and become le threatening. Overall, the coronavirus raised the risk of a severe maternal illness two-and-a-half times, researchers found.Pre-term births during early, middle, and late terms of the pregnancy doubled, while birth may need to be induced early when the mother has a condition such as pre-eclampsia, the study revealed.Dr Assiamira Ferrara, a lead author of the study at Calornia-based care consortium Kaiser Permanente, said: These findings add to growing evidence having Covid- during pregnancy raises risks of serious complications.The findings were based on , expectant women in the US of whom , became infected. Dr Ferrara added: Coupled with the evidence the Covid- vaccines are safe during pregnancy, these findings should aid patients in understanding the risks of perinatal complications and the need for vaccination. This study supports the recommendation for vaccination of pregnant iniduals and those planning conception. Calornia-based care consortium Kaiser Permanente tracked participants from before conception to delivery to identy links between before and after birth complications.  Covid was diagnosed through a PCR test by the researchers. The racially and ethnically erse group was followed from March  to March . Those who tested positive were more likely to be younger, obese, Hispanic, have had multiple babies or live in a poor neighbourhood, scientists said. Dr Mara Greenberg, a co-author of the study and a maternal-fetal medicine specialist, said: Our study was large, erse, and supports the need for vaccination by pregnant iniduals and those who plan to get pregnant. The most important thing people can do to protect themselves and their baby is to get vaccinated.  The analysis found almost six per cent of patients with a coronavirus infection during pregnancy had a related hospitalisation. That was most likely for black or Asian or Pacic islanders and patients with pre-gestational diabetes, the study found. Researchers compared patients who gave birth before and after December , when universal Covid testing of pregnant patients began. They found a positive test rate of . and . per cent, respectively. The same health risks applied to both groups. The US team is continuing to research Covid and pregnancy, focusing on telemedicine and health care delivery during the pandemic.  Dr Monique Hedderson, another study co-author, said: We are also planning to follow both mothers and children to study possible short and long-term health effects of coronavirus infections during pregnancy. In November analysis of , pregnant women in France found those with Covid were  times as likely to die during childbirth, scientists said. The study was published in JAMA Internal Medicine. title: ufo shaped clouds spotted skies
story: UFO-shaped clouds spotted in skies as Met Office explains rare unnatural phenomenaThe Met Office said that such lens-shaped clouds form when the air is stable and winds blow across hills and mountains from the same or similar direction at dferent heightsPeople were baffled by the phenomena Image: Declan OGara Edinburgh LiveByJohn Paul ClarkGraeme Murray:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsBaffled people have spotted UFO-shaped clouds which weather experts have explained are a rare phenomena.Seen across the country, the orb-shaped formation left people scratching their heads at the bizarre sight, EdinburghLive reports.Pictures of the unusual clouds, which formed over parts of Scotland, were shared by baffled eyewitnesses.Experts from the Met Office provided some insight into the unusual sightings which they described as lenticular clouds.The forecaster said that such lens-shaped clouds form when the air is stable and winds blow across hills and mountains from the same or similar direction at dferent heights. They are avoided by aeroplanes because they create in-flight turbulence.  But larger lenticular formations were pictured over northern Scotland and the borders earlier this year.A Met Office spokesperson told EdinburghLive : These strange, unnatural looking clouds sometimes form downwind of hills or mountains.They are quite unusual in the British Isles but do occasionally occur.“They look a lot like the traditional shape of flying saucers in science fiction, and real lenticular clouds are believed to be one of the most common explanations for UFO sightings across the world.When air blows across a mountain range, in certain circumstances, it can set up a train of large standing waves in the air downstream, rather like ripples forming in a river when water flows over an obstruction. If there is enough moisture in the air, the rising motion of the wave will cause water vapour to condense, forming the unique appearance of lenticular clouds. Lenticular clouds are a visible sign of mountain waves in the air. However, these waves can be present beyond the clouds, and may exist even when no clouds are formed. On the ground, they can result in very strong gusty winds in one place, with still air only a few hundred metres away. Pilots of powered aircraft tend to avoid flying near lenticular clouds because of the turbulence that accompany them. Skilledglider pilots, on the other hand, like them, because they can tell from the shape of the clouds where the air will be rising. This time last year , there was a combined total of , cases.However, England was just emerging from its latest lockdown - with Prime Minister Boris Johnson unveiling his roadmap for lockdown easing on February .At that time in , schools in England had reopened, recreation in outdoor public spaces was allowed between two people - but the stay at home order remained in effect. The latest vaccination figures, as of last Thursday , show ,, people in Britain have had the first dose. A total of ,, have had the second and a third booster dose has been received by ,,. It comes as over-s will aposprobablyapos get a fourth Covid vaccine dose this autumn, Sajid Javid declared today.The Health Secretary gave the strongest hint yet that there will be a wider rollout of ’second boosters’ - fourth doses overall - as cases rise and immunity wanes.It comes as it emerged the NHS was planning for a range of scenarios in a rollout between September and December - with eligible groups ranging from over-s and NHS care staff to all over-s.People aged  and over, and immunosuppressed over-s and adults, have been able to book a Spring booster since am today - as long as it’s at least six months since their last dose.For most people this will be their fourth dose, though for some immunosuppressed people it will be their fth.The Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisationis still debating whether to extend fourth doses more widely.  The JCVI has said a wider fourth dose rollout could be limited to some groups, and not be offered to all adults like the last booster programme. Meanwhile, pregnant women who catch Covid are twice as likely to develop serious complications and three times more likely to suffer a potentially fatal blood, according to scientists.With Coronavirus also doubling the risk of of premature birth, acute respiratory distress syndrome and sepsis, according to new research.Meanwhile, in the UK, mums-to-be who have not had the jab make up a fth of the most ill patients in intensive care, data showed. Infected patients who took part in this latest study were three times as likely to have a blood clot - known medically as a thromboembolism, scientists discovered. Thromboembolism can cause a blockage in the main artery of the lung or form where and become le threatening. Kaylie Williams, , was partying with four friends on the party island of Magaluf in  when she decided to get a tattoo. After bumping into a group of lads who were on a stag do, a man from the group offered to pay for her to get his name on her bum. When Kaylie woke up the next day, she found aposDaniel Fordeapos tattooed on her left bum cheek - the name of the person who paid for the €tattoo. After Daniel Forde had ed home to Cardf the next day, she has never seen him since and wants to get back in touch.Kaylie, a support worker from Hereford, said: I was on holiday in Magaluf and am a bit of party animal and I was just having a fun time with my friends. I was walking passed and I was drunk. Out of the blue, something popped into my head and I thought aposI will have a tattoo,apos quite a lot of people do when they are in places like Magaluf. story: Huge £k home is like Disney World for adults - with Tarzan rope swing between roomsA jungle-themed mansion is now on the market for £, and buyers will get the chance to live like a real-le Tarzan, even swinging from room to room on a huge rope swingThe estate agent is still looking for a unique buyer Image: Kennedy News City Center RealtyByJulia BanimAudience WriterAdam Wareing:,  Mar |comments An extraordinary house listing in Lakeport, Calornia, has gone viral, with social media users left fascinated by its incredible jungle-themed decor, like something out of Tarzan.With a giant wooden elephant, heaps of shrubbery, a swimming pool and even a rope to swing from room to room, owners have compared the three-bedroom property to aposDisney Worldapos for adults.City Center Realty shared pictures of the timber-framed house on property site Zillow, showing off the £,homeaposs striking open-plan layout, complete with second-floor balconies and an overhead bridge.Photographs show a giant rope dangling from the ft-tall ceiling right down to the floor, allowing wild homeowners to swing between rooms just like Tarzan himself. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. The property on been listed on Zillow since October , and City Center Realty have yet to find a suitable buyer. Estate agent Colleen Henninger has said that most of those who come to view the property just want to have a look at it, without any intention of buying. Although the asking price has since dropped from .million to .million in that time, itaposs still currently the priciest listed home currently on Zillow in Lakeport. The unique home comes with . acres of land, filled with trees ready to climb, plus a large swimming pool in its back garden which you could pretend is your own jungle lagoon. title: my mum tried control wedding
story: My mum tried to control my wedding - now shes cut me off because I elopedA woman has vented her frustration after her own mum tried to take over her wedding planning - and then completely cut her off after she decided to elope insteadThe woman said her mums demands were driving her crazyImage: Getty Images Tetra images RFByZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Mar |comments A wedding day should be about celebrating the couple that is tying the knot - and no matter how much other loved ones might want to help plan the big day, the couple should be the ones to make any final decisions. But thataposs not the experience one woman on Reddit had after her mum completely took over the planning for her wedding and controlled things so much she pushed her daughter to want to elope instead. In her post, the woman claimed she initially only wanted a maximum of  people at her wedding, but her mum had made a guest list of  and had been pushing her to go down the traditional route. She said: My fiancé proposed in October of ! I was thrilled of course and immediately told my mum and dad - Iaposm an only child so they were also thrilled. My mum immediately began planning which is great, I can use all the help I could get, but it turned into multiple daily texts and demands.Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Our list was - people, hers was . I wanted a smaller unique wedding, she wanted traditional. I wanted a vintage style gown from , she wanted me in a ball gown. It was driving me CRAZY. The stress was making me sick and I was avoiding all contact with her because I just couldnapost do it. Eventually, the woman asked her partnerhe would be okay with eloping instead, and when he was on board they decided to tell her mum about their plan - which only made things worse. She added: She handled it surprisingly well at first, and we thought we may actually get what we wanted - a private, no fuss, quiet time with a friend there to sign the paper and spending the rest of the day just the two of us doing whatever we love. But no. My mother had to make it about her.  It started with her trying to plan a small ceremony at my future mother-in-lawaposs house with my fiancéaposs stepfather officiating. Not once had we mentioned wanting to have the ceremony nevermind at someoneaposs house, but my mum brought the plans up to my mother-in-law, despite me telling her thanks but no thanks. I had to be blunt with my mother after that. Not only had she tried to take charge of this, but she had gone behind our backs and tried to make it happen when we said no. The woman told her mum that all she wanted was to sign the marriage certicate with her fiancé and have her friend - who is also a photographer - witness the signing as well as take a few photos.  Earlier this month, the woman and her now-husband went ahead and eloped as planned, and even let her mum plan a celebratory dinner after the event as a compromise. She explained: We eloped on March . My friend did the photoshoot for us and we exchanged rings and vows, even got to have our first dance in a beautul old train station - it was everything we wanted. My mother wasnapost happy about not being a part of our vows photoshoot ring exchange dance but we had compromised and had dinner with the entire family. She chose the place, picked a cake, chose who we invited, and all that rubbish. But you know what - I had an amazing time with my new husband and my amazing friend, we were still able to keep our spirits up despite her taking over the dinner, and we got married! And while the woman is over the moon with her marriage and the way the wedding turned out, her mum is now refusing to speak to her and has made little to no contact with her since the wedding day. She said: Since then, my mum has been little to no contact despite letting me know she would be kicking me off her insurance for my car and I needed to figure it out. Iaposm honestly fine with the limited contact and my stress has been greatly reduced because of it. It sucks that I canapost ever be the daughter she wants but Iaposm sick of my boundaries being ignored. My husband and I are planning a reception during the summer to celebrate and are making sure she has absolutely nothing to do with it until she receives the invite a month before. F**k it. title: spooky church snapped up home
story: Spooky church snapped up as home - complete with ghost of bloodthirsty black houndThe chapel in Cwmbran, South Wales, was once surrounded by woodland when it was built in the th century is haunted by a baying hound after a former minister heard its blood-curdling howlsThe chapel in St Dials, Wales Image: Paul Fosh Auctions WALES NEWS SERVICEByGraeme Murray:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsA spooky church has been snapped up as a home and even comes with the ghost of a bloodthirsty black hound, according to legend. House-hunting horror fans had a bidding war at an auction for the stone-built chapel which is built next to a graveyard. It was once surrounded by woodland when it was built in the th century - and legend says it is even haunted by a baying hound after claims a former minister heard its blood-curdling howls. Folklore has it that a former minister saw the great black beast before striking it between the eyes with his Bible. The property is believed to be haunted by the black hound of the underworld in Cwmbran, South Wales.  The mythical creature is said to have burst into flames and disappeared - leaving the clergyman with a singed beard. The chapel in St Dials went under the hammer with a guide price of £, - but sold for £, more after  bids from three bidders. Property seekers will soon discover, it is built in the centre a new suburb. And sellers say it could be let out as a quirky airbnb let and would provide peace and quiet and be unlikely to be disturbed by new-build home owners. The chapelaposs spooky history and legends are likely to deter many would-be owners butsomeone has an interest in the supernatural, it might make a dream home a dream. They say its history would make it a fine property which could be converted for everyday use. Despite dating back to the th century, it has no planning restrictions in place and is not a listed building. This will give the new buyer a bank canvas and either allow them to preserve its ancient history or incorporate it in any development.  Debra Bisley, of Paul Fosh Auctions, said: I donapost know about the mysterious Black Hound and the ministeraposs beard but the chapel and graveyard is certainly unusual plonked as it is in the middle of the modern estate. Sympathetically converted it could make a lovely house or may be an unusual airbnb property. There would be no nuisance or noise from the immediate neighbours. The detached chapel, of stone construction under a pitch tiled roof, is believed to date back to the th century. Itaposs understood not to be listed and has planning for conversion to residential uses. The site also offers potential for the creation of off road parking. title: demand swiss expel vladimir putins
story: Demand for Swiss to expel Vladimir Putins lover from her luxury mountain boltholeAlina Kabaeva is seldom seen in public but was caught on video dancing in Moscow in December amid fears Vladimir Putin was planning to go to war in Ukraine and she is now living in SwitzerlandVladimir Putin hands flowers to Alina Kabaeva Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByGraeme MurrayWill StewartRussia Correspondent:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsThere are demands for the Swiss to expel Vladimir Putinaposs reported lover from her luxury mountain bolthole.Foes of Putin in Russia and Ukraine are uniting with a petition calling on the Swiss expel his “lover” Alina Kabaeva, , amid claims she is hiding with their secret children in a luxury villa.“It’s time you reunite Eva Braun with her Führer,” says the incendiary petition. The critics say: “Despite the current war, Switzerland continues to host an accomplice of Putin’s regime.” It added that it was time for the neutral country “to take action” and send her home to Putin, .Kabaeva is seldom seen in public - but was caught on video dancing in Moscow in December amid fears Putin was planning to go to war in Ukraine. Recent reports have claimed she is seeing out the war with her rumoured children in a mountain retreat in Switzerland.“We, the citizens of Russia, Belarus and Ukraine, which is currently undergoing immense suffering, are uniting to appeal to the Swiss authorities,” states the petition in German, French and English and posted on change.org, so far signed by almost ,.“The public has just learned that the Russian political and media figure, and former [rhythmic gymnast], Alina Kabaeva, is hiding the consequences of the sanctions imposed on the Russian Federation in your country.  “She is the favourite we of [the] delusional dictator and war criminal who has been treacherously attacking Ukraine over the past weeks. “As she is supportive of social activities in Russia, she has been attempting to get Russian citizens accustomed to the reality of sanctions after , and personally proclaimed: ‘The worse it gets, the better for us!’” The signatories question why “given the volume of sanctions placed on Russia” the authorities continue to host her and her family at a time when Putin “is destroying the lives of millions”. The West has so far not sanctioned Kabaeva - although as well as being Putin’s rumoured secret partner, she is also chairman of the board of directors at National Media Group, a major Kremlin-obedient TV and newspaper behemoth, at a salary of almost £ million a year. The petition tells the Swiss: For the first time in modern history, your country has violated its neutrality, which it did not even do vis-à-vis Nazi Germany in the th century, and joined the sanctions against Putin and his surroundings.“And now you are allowing his favourite mistress and her children to hide within the borders of your state.” There is as yet no independent evidence that Kabaeva, a former pro-Putin MP, is hiding in Switzerland, where she was rumoured to have previously given birth in the country. It adds: “We want to remind you that Alina Kabaeva is not only a woman who stained herself with an association with the Russian dictator, but also a criminal against humanity. “In particular, she was among the initiators of the draft law, which in Russia was called the “law of scoundrels” or “the law of Dima Yakovlev. “This shameful move deprived thousands of Russian orphans of the possibility of being adopted abroad. “Consequently, many applications already open at the time for the adoption of seriously ill children were canceled and applicants for qualied medical care simply died. “Alina Kabaeva, [then] a member of the State Duma [parliament], obediently approved any unconstitutional initiative of President Putin, which later became almost genocidal against the internal population of Russia.”  They call for the Swiss to “investigate very carefully the legal basis on which she is present in your country. It adds: “Please consider it especially against the backdrop of sanctions imposed on her as a top executive of Russian propaganda media. “Please decide whether the residence of this inidual in your country is warranted. “We also ask you to check the ‘cleanliness’ of the funds used for the purchase of real estate in Switzerland, of which this person uses. “We will seek justice in any way possible, andthe fact of corruption of inidual political officials of Switzerland is found out, which has allowed Alina Kabaeva to obtain citizenship bypassing all procedures, then we will ensure that this information isn’t kept a secret. “At times like this, filled with tremendous uncertainty, you must be severe with your actions and in regards to the beneficiaries of Putinaposs regime!“It’s time you reunite Eva Braun with her Führer!” Separate reports suggest Kabaeva is not in Switzerland but at a hi-tech underground bunker in the Altai Mountains of Siberia. Political scientist Valery Solovey, , linked to the Telegram channel, said earlier this month: “In fact, it is not a bunker, but a whole underground city, equipped with the latest science and technology.” He warned: “I hope this means something to you  “That the President sends his family to this bunker.” In her only statement linked to the war, Kabaeva slammed the refusal to allow the Russian team to compete at the Beijing Paralympics.  “There has never been a more shameful page in the history of world sports,” she said. “They did not worry and did not remove from the competition any country that participated in the destruction of hundreds of thousands of civilians in Yugoslavia, Iraq, Libya, and Syria. “But sports officials were very angry when Russia decided to protect the Donbas and Luhansk from the Nazis. She complained that Olympic officials “tried so hard to humiliate the Russians, banned our symbols, flag and anthem”. But still Russians succeeded due to the talent of our athletes. “Russia was, is and will be a great sports power - and you canapost do anything about it. Rumours first linked her romantically to Putin as long ago as  when she was a pro-Kremlin MP. Tabloid Express Gazeta recounted in May when she was still out of sight: “She literally vanished. “After the giving-birth-to-twins reports nothing was heard about Kabaeva, asshe had disappeared. “Alina is not giving interviews, nor attending social events, nor participating in any TV programmes. “One can only guess what is happening in her private le.” Putin - who in  announced his orce from we Lyudmila, a former Aeroflot stewardess - has previously said: I have a private le in which I do not permit interference. It must be respected.” He deplored those who with their snotty noses and erotic fantasies prowl into othersapos lives”. Kabaeva is on record as saying she had met a man who I love very much”, gushing: Sometimes you feel so happy that you even feel scared. However the Russian media - including her own newspaper and TV group - throws no light on whether they are or were a couple. In  Kabaeva was temporarily banned from competing in rhythmic gymnastics after failing a doping test. A year earlier she had won gold at the  summer Olympics. Once regarded as Russia’s most eligible woman, the only other suitor she has been linked to by the media was a married Georgian policeman. This relationship petered out in  amid complaints of tabloid intrusion into her le. She once posed almost nude for Maxim and was described as “full of sex” by a photographer. There have been many reports of her wearing a wedding ring, but no records of a marriage. She is reported to have a fleet of Maybach limousines at her disposal, and was seen surrounded by a squad of machine-gun toting security guards on visits to a Moscow cafe. Many Russians saw her as the reason for the breakup of Putin’s marriage to ex-first lady Lyudmila, , mother of his two adult daughters. The dictator of neighbouring Belarus, Alexander Lukashenko hinted that Putinaposs orce decision came about because Kabaeva put pressure on the president. title: inside vladimir putins hidden fortune
story: Inside Vladimir Putins hidden fortune with presidential palace and  million yachtRussia has the largest amount of wealth hidden in offshore tax havens, both in terms of absolute volume, and percentage of GDP. Putins government salary is just , a year and he is estimated to be worth bnVladimir Putins presidential palace alone boasts an amphitheater, underground hockey rink and private seaportByCurt DevineCasey TolanMajlie de Puy KampSamantha Mordi:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsIt is widely known that Russian president Vladimir Putin is one of the richest men on earth but how exactly does he amass - and maintain - his fortune  For a man estimated to be worth  billion, Putinaposs presidential palace alone boasts an amphitheatre, underground hockey rink and private seaport. The palace stands in contrast to the tiny -square-foot apartment Putin claims in his most recent financial disclosure. Experts say the palace symbolises an era of Putin pursuing a luxurious lestyle that he could never afford on his , government salary. There is a no-fly zone in the skies above the residence and a no-boating zone in the surrounding waters.However, working out the intricacies of Putinaposs wealth is a dficult task, CNN Business reports.Gary Kalman, the director of the US office of Transparency International said: It is extraordinarily dficult for law enforcement to try and aposfollow the moneyapos because at some point you are going to literally hit a brick wall. There is literally no paper trail.  It is believed that Putin is believed to have amassed a hidden fortune by such means earlier in his career. The -year-old has become less reliant on his wealthy benefactors over the years and has surrounded himself with government and military loyalists.Some Russia experts say it may make it more dficult to make Putin personally feel the sting of economic sanctions the US and its European allies have imposed to punish him for invading Ukraine.He is rumoured to own or have access to not only the Black Sea palace, but also a  million yacht, according to unconfirmed reports. The Kremlin has dismissed reports of Putinaposs purported hidden wealth. Maria Pevchikh, head of investigations Navalnyaposs Anti-Corruption Foundation said: He sees himself as a czar, as king of some sort. He has huge plans. He has the vision of him being a historical figure, being so powerful, so mighty, so important, and they invest a lot of money into this narrative. The assets tied to Putinaposs inner circle include an apartment in a Monaco luxury building overlooking the principalityaposs glitzy harbour. The fourth-floor flat was purchased in  for . million by a shell corporation called Brockville Development Ltd., a company registered in the British Virgin Islands.Russia has the largest amount of wealth hidden in offshore tax havens, both in terms of absolute volume - estimates peg it around  billion in  - and as a percentage of national GDP, according to a  report by the Atlantic Council. On average, % of world GDP is held offshore. However, in Russia, offshore wealth accounted for as much as % of GDP in , according to a  Journal of Public Economics research paper, the most recent estimate available. title: kate caribbean tour faces more
story: Kate and Will Caribbean tour faces more protests after villagers saw trip cancelledKate Middleton and Prince Williams Caribbean tour could be marred by further protests in Jamaica - as campaigners accuse the Queen and her predecessors of perpetuating slaveryThe Duke and Duchess of Cambridge are on a royal visit in the Caribbean Image: Getty ImagesByRussell Myers, Royal Editor in BelizeRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Mar |comments Prince William and Kate Middletonaposs Caribbean tour could be marred by further protests in Jamaica, as campaigners accuse the Queen and her predecessors of perpetuating slavery.The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge arrive on the island tomorrow from Belize on the next leg of their three-country visit before going to The Bahamas on Thursday. As the country marks its th anniversary, a coalition of Jamaican politicians, business leaders, doctors and musicians have called in an open letter for the British monarchy to pay slavery reparations.The letter reads: We note with great concern your visit to our country Jamaica, during a period when we are still in the throes of a global pandemic and bracing for the full impact of another global crisis associated with the Russian  Ukraine war.We see no reason to celebrate  years of the ascension of your grandmother to the British throne because her leadership, and that of her predecessors, has perpetuated the greatest human rights tragedy in the history of humankind. The group Advocates Network, a human rights coalition of Jamaican activists and equalities organisations, will stage a protest outside the British High Commission in Kingston at .am just hours before Prince William and Kate arrive.  Co-organiser of the protest Nora Blake told The Independent: “It is important as we turn  years old as an independent nation that we stand as “adults” on solid ethical, moral and human justice grounds to say to Britain, who was once our “parent”, that you have done wrong in enriching yourselves off of chattel slavery and colonialism. “Morally this requires an apology, and it is only just that reparations be made. “Many precedents have been set for this.  “Today we are setting the conversation of our future generations, for them to have something to build a brighter future.” Numbers willing to participate in the protest have not been confirmed but organisers say it is backed by  figures from a wide cross-section of industries including politics, business, the clergy and arts. Signatories also include iconic reggae artist Big Youth and Mike Henry - one of Jamaica’s longest-serving MPs.  Directly addressing Prince William, who with we Kate is undertaking the tour to firm up relations with the Caribbean realms and celebrate the Queen’s  years on the throne, the letter states: “We will not participate in your Platinum Jubilee celebration! It adds: We are of the view that an apology for British crimes against humanity, including but not limited to, the exploitation of the indigenous people of Jamaica, the transatlantic trafficking of Africans, the enslavement of Africans, indentureship and colonialisation, is necessary to begin a process of healing, forgiveness, reconciliation and compensation.”  In sync with Jamaica’s th independence later this year, the protest group has issued the royals with a -point breakdown detailing reasons why this is warranted. The apparent opposition in Jamaica comes after the tour began in controversial circumstances when opposition from villagers in Belize, who cited a range of issues including objections to the Cambridgesapos helicopter landing site, forced a royal trip to a farm on Sunday to be scrapped. It was replaced with a visit to a chocolate producer before the royals travelled to the cultural centre of the Garuna community in Hopkins.  The Cambridges are todaydue to visit stunning ancient Maya ruins deep in the heartland of Belize. William and Kate will be given a tour of the site and have the chance to take in Caana, or sky palace, which remains the tallest man-made structure in Belize. The duke visited Belize as a teenager in , when he reportedly learned jungle survival techniques with the Welsh Guards who were receiving training from the British Army Training Support Unit as part of Exercise Native Trail.  William was beginning a gap year before university at the time and while in the jungle, the then -year-old duke learned his A level results. The last engagement of the day will see the couple attend a reception hosted by the Governor-General of Belize at the Maya ruins at Cahal Pech, near San Ignacio. This special reception will be held in celebration of the Queenaposs Platinum and William will give a speech. During their first full day in Belize on Sunday, the couple toured a cocoa farm and danced during a cultural visit to a nearby village.
